extraction.summary: This is the preface and table of contents from Polya's 'How to Solve It,' which presents a systematic approach to problem-solving grounded in heuristic methods. The work argues that teaching students to understand problem-solving processes, not just solutions, develops their intellectual abilities and creates lasting engagement with mathematics and logical thinking.
key_claims: There is a grain of discovery in the solution of any problem
Mathematics has two faces: the rigorous Euclidean deductive science and mathematics in the making as an experimental, inductive science
Teaching routine operations kills student interest and misuses the teacher's opportunity
Problem-solving ability can be developed and taught through systematic methods
Mathematics is perceived as the least popular subject in school curricula due to how it is taught
Understanding the motives and procedures of solution is as important as knowing the solution itself
processes: Understanding the problem: identify the unknown, data, and condition; check if condition is satisfiable, sufficient, redundant, or contradictory; draw figures; introduce notation
Devising a plan: find connection between data and unknown; consider auxiliary problems; review related problems and theorems; restate the problem from different angles
Carrying out the plan: execute the solution while checking each step for correctness
Looking back: verify the result and argument; derive the result differently; apply the method to other problems
decisions: Is the condition sufficient to determine the unknown, or is it insufficient, redundant, or contradictory?
Should auxiliary problems be introduced when immediate connection cannot be found?
Should the problem be restated or approached from a different angle?
Should a more general, more special, or analogous problem be solved first?
Have all the data and conditions been used?
failures: Teachers who fill time with drilling routine operations kill student interest and hamper intellectual development
Students who regard mathematics only as a subject for earning credit lose the opportunity to develop problem-solving ability
Mathematics presented only in Euclidean form misses the experimental, inductive aspect of how mathematics is actually created
aha_moments: The author's realization as a student that understanding how solutions are invented is as important as understanding the solutions themselves
Recognition that mathematics has never before been presented to students in the process of being invented ('in statu nascendi')
Understanding that problem-solving experiences at a susceptible age create lasting tastes for mental work and shape character
The insight that mathematics can be as enjoyable as a crossword puzzle or physical game
metaphors: Mathematics has two faces: Euclidean rigorous science versus experimental, inductive science in the making
Solving problems is like tasting raspberry pie - you cannot know you like it until you experience it
Mental work can be 'an exercise as desirable as a fast game of tennis'
temporal: Before the book: heuristic study was not in fashion; mathematics presented only in rigorous Euclidean manner
After understanding problem-solving methods: mathematics becomes something that can be a hobby, tool of profession, or great ambition
High school teaching: students are taught to detest mathematics; they return as teachers and teach a new generation to detest it
quotes: Yes, the solution seems to work, it appears to be correct; but how is it possible to invent such a solution?
Mathematics has two faces; it is the rigorous science of Euclid but it is also something else.

Behind the desire to solve this or that problem that confers no material advantage, there may be a deeper curiosity, a desire to understand the ways and means, the motives and procedures, of solution.

extraction.summary: This introduction explains the structure and purpose of 'How to Solve It,' a influential mathematical problem-solving guide originally written by Polya in German during the 1930s and published in English in 1945. The book is organized into four parts: classroom applications, a teacher-student dialogue, a dictionary of heuristic techniques, and practice problems with solutions.
key_claims: Polya held a professorship at Stanford from 1943 until retirement in 1953
How to Solve It was written in German in Zürich and ended in 1940
Four publishers rejected the English version before Princeton University Press published it in 1945
How to Solve It became one of the most successful mathematical books of all time
Polya proved the Central Limit Theorem terminology and random walk properties
Polya independently re-enumerated the seventeen plane crystallographic groups
Polya's Enumeration Theorem is a standard method for counting configurations by symmetry
processes: Addressing heuristic questions and suggestions to yourself to solve your own problem
Using the same questions and suggestions with students to help them solve problems
Consulting the Dictionary for specific points arising from personal problem-solving experience
decisions: The list can be applied from either the student perspective or the teacher perspective
Readers can consult the Dictionary selectively based on particular points from their experience
The Dictionary should not be read quickly due to condensed and subtle text
failures: Four publishers rejected the English version of How to Solve It before Princeton University Press accepted it
aha_moments: Recognition that heuristic techniques can be systematically taught and applied to problem-solving
The realization that the same questioning approach works whether addressing oneself or a student
metaphors: The Dictionary as a reference tool requiring careful, experience-informed reading
temporal: Polya's time in Zürich ended in 1940 when the European situation forced him to leave for the United States
How to Solve It was written during Polya's time in Zürich before 1940

quotes: If, using them properly, you address these questions and suggestions to yourself, they may help you to solve your problem. If, using them properly, you address the same questions and suggestions to one of your students, you may help him to solve his problem.

extraction.summary: This section from a problem-solving guide explains the stages of carrying out and reviewing mathematical solutions, then introduces analogy as a powerful heuristic tool. It demonstrates how solving simpler analogous problems (like finding a triangle's center of gravity) can model solutions to more complex ones (like a tetrahedron's center of gravity), and discusses how analogical reasoning supports mathematical discovery and conjecture.

processes: Carrying out a plan: secure your grasp, carry through all operations, convince yourself of correctness through formal reasoning or intuitive insight, distinguish great steps from small steps, check great steps first
